metadata.case_name: Jugal Kishore and Amar Nath v. Dhiyan Singh and Jai Bhagwan Singh

facts.text: Common ancestor Megh Raj Singh had sons Jawahar Singh, Madan Singh, Shanker Lal (d. 1884).
Shanker Lal's daughter Mst. Mohan Dei (d. Oct. 1929), her husband Narain Das (d. 21-5-1940? text says 1921? wait 1921), son Shri Kishan Das (d. March 1929).
Other branch: Brijlal (d. 1890, plaintiffs' grandfather), his sons Kishan Lal, Mahabir Prasad.
Plaintiffs: Jugal Kishore (Plff 1), Amar Nath (Plff 2), claim as next reversioners after Shri Kishan Das predeceased Mst. Mohan Dei.
Defendants: Dhiyan Singh (Deft. 1), Jai Bhagwan Singh (Deft. 2), grandsons of Mst. Mohan Dei.
Two branches of family were separate at all material times.
Dispute about property forming part of Shanker Lal's estate; plaintiffs claim Mst. Mohan Dei succeeded to limited estate, reversion opened on her death in Oct. 1929 to plaintiffs.

On Shanker Lal's death in 1884, disputes between Brijlal (plaintiffs' grandfather) and Mst. Mohan Dei (defendants' grandmother); Brijlal claimed entire estate by survivorship as joint family property.
Dispute referred to arbitration; award (Ex. A-1) dated 21-12-1884 gave suit properties to Mst. Mohan Dei as absolute owner, rest to Brijlal.
Division effected per award; each branch in separate and uninterrupted possession from 21-12-1884 to 26-3-1941 (suit date), dealing as absolute owners.
Suit filed on 26-3-1941; plaintiffs lost in first court, won in High Court; defendants appeal.
Brijlal died 1889 or 1890; Shri Kishan Das survived him till March 1929.
Mst. Mohan Dei gifted suit property to grandsons (defendants) on 4th April 1929; mutation effected, Kishan Lal raised no objection.
Kishan Lal and brother partitioned their estate, sold parts to third parties; knew of award, mutation per award.
Dhiyan Singh (DW 2) testified Kishan Lal always accepted and acted on award; objection if any was after Mohan Dei's death.

legal_issues.text: Whether the award gave Mst. Mohan Dei an absolute estate or only a limited estate.
Whether plaintiffs are bound by the award or estopped from challenging it.

petitioner_arguments.text: Award gave Mst. Mohan Dei only limited estate; earlier passages in award show intention for limited estate; arbitrator confused on facts and law.
Award invalid as arbitrator exceeded reference; even if Brijlal bound, Kishan Lal had independent reversioner title, not bound; plaintiffs not bound.

respondent_arguments.text: Award gave Mst. Mohan Dei absolute estate via clear words 'malik mustaqil'; parties bound and estopped.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Ram Gopal v. Nand Lal (1950 SCR 766); Bishunath Prasad Singh v. Chandika Prasad Kumari (1933 60 IA 56)

respondent_arguments.text: Estoppel against Brijlal, descended to Kishan Lal and plaintiffs; long possession and acting on award.

court_reasoning.text: Award's operative portion unambiguously gives absolute estate to Mst. Mohan Dei via 'each party has become permanent owner malik mustaqil of his or her share'; earlier passages do not qualify it.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words admit of no doubt; arbitrator confused but clear language prevails.

court_reasoning.text: Even if award invalid, estoppel arises: Brijlal represented acceptance of award giving absolute estate, induced Mohan Dei to detriment; she parted with property.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Estoppel by conduct in accepting and acting on award for decades.

court_reasoning.text: Estoppel binds Kishan Lal: took possession through father, no independent title then, acted on award, full knowledge, inaction for 40 years.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Kishan Lal estopped even in reversioner character per Kanhai Lal v. Brij Lal.

court_reasoning.text: Estoppel descends to plaintiffs claiming through Kishan Lal.
Distinguishes Rangasami Gounden and Mt. Binda Kuer: here Kishan Lal held solely under award, no independent title portion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Full benefit derived solely from award acceptance.

holdings.text: Award conferred absolute estate on Mst. Mohan Dei.
Plaintiffs estopped from claiming as reversioners due to conduct of Brijlal, Kishan Lal.

precedents_cited.relevance: Meaning of 'malik mustaqil' as absolute owner.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bishunath Prasad Singh v. Chandika Prasad Kumari
precedents_cited.relevance: Meaning of 'malik mustaqil' as absolute owner.
Estoppel binds consenting reversioner even in new character; similar facts of compromise acted on.
Party benefiting from transaction estopped from questioning it.
No estoppel where independent title exists; differs as here no such title.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mt. Binda Kuer v. Lalitha Prasad
precedents_cited.relevance: No estoppel for portion with independent title; here entire holding under award.

outcome.summary: Appeal succeeds; decree of High Court set aside, decree of first court dismissing plaintiffs' claim restored.

key_quotes.text: 'each party has become permanent owner malik mustaqil of his or her share'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Operative words of award conferring absolute estate.

key_quotes.text: We do not think the words admit of any doubt, particularly as the words malik mustaqil have been used
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court's interpretation of award as absolute.

key_quotes.text: by his conduct Brijlal induced Mst. Mohan Dei to believe that this would be the case and on the faith of that representation... acted greatly to her detriment
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Kishanlal always accepted this award and acted upon it
key_quotes.speaker: respondent_counsel
